Description: Terracotta flask in the shape of a bunch of grapes. A flask modelled in the round as a bunch of grapes; a circular aperture in the top. Made in a two-piece mould, with many separately made grapes applied to the surface. Micaceous brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: Made of brown, micaceous Nile clay. Mould lines removed before grapes applied.

BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. For better-modelled grape flasks, see: Allen 1985: no. 131, from Karanis, dated first century ad or earlier; Besques 1992: no. D/E 4554, from Middle Egypt, dated late Hellenistic; Breccia 1934: pl. cviii:621; Fischer 1994: no. 1251, dated Roman period; Fjeldhagen 1995: no. 207, dated first century bc/ad; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 123: 1; Schreiber 1908: 231, fig. 163, from Alexandria; Van Wijngaarden 1958: no. 99.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3784)
